Description: Asymmetrical bronze axe-head: with inclined butt and a relatively broad waist with slightly incurved sides. One of the sides, the uppermost when the blade was hafted, is longer than the other. Both sides are bevelled. The blade has been cleaned of corrosion product. It is in poor condition. It has corroded into laminae at the cutting end and is also damaged at the rear, where one of the lugs is lost. Chased in one face is a representation of a boat accompanied by hieroglyphic inscriptions.
Curator's comments: Bibliography: P. E. Newberry, ‘Proceedings of the Society of Biblical Archaeology’ 24 (London, 1902), 250, no. 35; E. A. Wallis Budge 'A Guide to the Fourth, Fifth and Sixth Egyptian Rooms, and the Coptic Room' (London, 1922), 201, no. 4, with fig.; A. R. Schulman, 'Military Rank, Title, and Organization in the Egyptian New Kingdom' (Berlin, 1964), 137, ref. 323,f; E. Kühnert-Eggesbrecht, ‘Die Axt als Waffe und Werkzeug im alten Ägypten’ (Berlin, 1969), 59-60 and 133, P 12, pl. XVIII, 2.
Bibliographic references: Davies 1987 / Catalogue of Egyptian Antiquities in the British Museum (156)
